alert.note: Alert for Coffee; Dale; Geneva; Henry; Houston (Alabama) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Hydrologic Outlook issued February 09 at 2:02PM CST by NWS Tallahassee
info.description: ...MULTIPLE ROUNDS OF HEAVY RAIN EXPECTED FROM FRIDAY THROUGH SATURDAY NIGHT... ...MINOR TO MODERATE RIVER FLOODING POSSIBLE LATE THIS WEEKEND AND EARLY NEXT WEEK... ...ISOLATED FLASH FLOODING POSSIBLE... .Flood Potential and Impacts... Forecast rainfall amounts continue to increase, especially across the I-75 corridor in South Central Georgia. This continues to raise the potential for riverine and flash flooding across South Georgia, Southeast Alabama, and North Florida. Multiple rounds of heavy rain are expected on Friday and Saturday, due to a slow-moving cold front on Friday, then an additional storm system passing by on Saturday. These rounds of heavy rain are now forecast to add up to 3 to 4 inches over a widespread portion of the region. Localized totals of 6 to 8 inches are possible, especially in places where thunderstorms repeatedly train over the same areas like along Interstate 75 in South Georgia and adjacent areas of the Florida Big Bend. Rises are expected on all area rivers. Broadly speaking, river basins picking up 4 inches of rain can expect minor flooding. Basins picking up 6 inches of rain could experience moderate flooding. Riverine flooding could begin as soon as Saturday night into Sunday morning. Based on the latest forecast, river systems with headwaters in Georgia and Alabama have the greatest potential of getting the heaviest rain. Thus, rivers of greater concern for flooding include the Kinchafoonee, Muckalee, Ochlockonee, Withlacoochee, Choctawhatchee, Pea, Shoal, and the combined Chattahoochee / Flint / Apalachicola River systems. Looking ahead, another storm system could affect the region late next week. Though it is too early to speculate on rainfall amounts, the region will be vulnerable to flooding following this weekend`s heavy rainfall. .Preparedness Actions... With the models continuing to show an increased likelihood of a heavy rainfall event, a flood watch may be issued for a portion of our area as soon as Friday morning. People living near small streams and area rivers should be alert to rapid rises in water level and be prepared to take action if warnings are issued. Residents living in areas vulnerable to flash flooding should consider evaluating their flood risk and be prepared to take action to protect themselves and property from flood damage. For more information be sure to interact with our office through twitter @NWSTALLAHASSEE.
